title: What is the meaning behind BTS 'Silver Spoon (Baepsae)' song? - Quora

response.answer_text: Baepsae is a song about BTS themselves. There are many meanings and interpretations made by ARMYs. I'll run you through what I thought, however, it could be another meaning that you end up liking. It's your choice. But let me start from the top. Baepsae is the name of a type of bird that’s called ‘crow-tit,’ or a ‘parrotbill.’ So essentially, there's an idiom in Korean that refers to the ‘baepsae’ attempting to walk like a stork but then breaking its legs as it’s legs are shorter than that of a stork. It represents that the baepsae, while attempting to be like the stork, only ruins itself while trying to imitate something/someone better. Simpler words: it’s an idiom used for someone "trying hard" to achieve something or be better than someone else.  So, now, main topic. BTS are under the management of what once was a small company, compared to the Big 3: YG, SM and JYP. They are a younger generation, and they are told to work harder to harder to not suffer in the future, and also to ‘ensure their success.’ The Big 3 have no worries as to whether their groups will be a hit or not. Being such a successful entertainment agency, the groups already have a great life of not that much effort to put in. So unlike the ‘upper class,’ such as YG, JYP and SM, they have to work harder and put more effort. They exclaim that they are called as ‘try-hards’ by people, and that they're tired of being told to try harder and harder. They say that the artists who came before them want to keep their reign over the sales, and charts and the hearts of Koreans, and that the rules are all made of such standard that the younger generation is at a disadvantage, and that it isn't fair. They also say that they are blamed for not being to equalize with the groups who came before them, or be bigger than them, and answer with ‘you must be kidding me.’ That's all I remember, for now. I may keep updating it as I go. But I don't think there's much to it. I hope you got the gist of it.

Everyone knows Baepsae as an upbeat, easy to get into the mood song but if we really dive deep into the lyrics, it’s quite inspiring how BTS is breaking the status quo with this song. Baepsae is a bird in Korea translated as “Crow Tit” — I know, let’s not judge the translation please, they look like very cute birds. Anyway, opposite a Crow Tit is a Stork. Crow Tits have short legs, Storks have long legs. In personification, Crow Tits are like those people in society who are middle class, “silver spoons” while Storks are those people in society who are high class, “gold spoons”. There are a lot more “spoons” in Korea that signify hierarchy but I will only mention these two because it’s in the song. BTS sings about how Storks don’t have to work as hard in getting to their destination because they have longer legs, they have this sort of “privilege” by birth. When you’re a born Crow Tit, you either make it into the industry by working hard or working hard. There is no other way in winning, there is only effort. The only thing you have is your talent and your passion to succeed, but in a corrupt society, hardwork doesn’t always win. Storks, get the money, opportunity and networks since birth, they wake up to a life where they exert effort and their effort is already rewarded, it was a given already. This is what BTS is calling out in the society, the unfairness of the old generation saying that their hardwork will be repaid one day, as long as they work hard and exert effort. Lucky and blessed for BTS hardwork did work for them, but for some, hardwork isn’t everything. Saying that the Big Company privilege is a lie is literally delusional, open your eyes to reality and realize that KPop is just another industry thriving off from the money of fandoms.  This answer took so long but I hope this helped. Been a bit busy with work and life lately, been a hiatus ARMY but still love BTS so much. My answer is mainly derived from Muish’ interpretation. Please do visit her blog it’s been very helpful in trying to understand BTS in a more cultural manner.
